header.name: chaos/preprocessor/repetition/for_aux.h
header.author: Paul Mensonides
header.overview: The header defines a predicated repetition algorithm.

macro.abstract: The macro is a predicated repetition construct.

param.para:
The predicate that determines whether the algorithm should continue. This predicate must be either a or a macro name that refers to a macro with a signature compatible with the following pseudo-signature:
pred(s, data†, state‡)

† If the auxiliary data is parenthetic, the data pseudo-parameter must be the number of parameters that corresponds to the number of sub-elements in the auxiliary data. Otherwise, it must be a single parameter.
‡ The state pseudo-parameter must be either ... or the number of parameters that corresponds to the number of arguments in the initial state, __VA_ARGS__.

The operation used to iterate the state. This operation must be either a or a macro name that refers to a macro with a signature compatible with the following pseudo-signature:
op(s, data†, state‡)

† If the auxiliary data is parenthetic, the data pseudo-parameter must be the number of parameters that corresponds to the number of sub-elements in the auxiliary data. Otherwise, it must be a single parameter.
‡ The state pseudo-parameter must be either ... or the number of parameters that corresponds to the number of arguments in the initial state, __VA_ARGS__.

The target to be repeated. This target must be either a or a macro name that refers to a macro with a signature compatible with the following pseudo-signature:
macro(s, data†, state‡)

† If the auxiliary data is parenthetic, the data pseudo-parameter must be the number of parameters that corresponds to the number of sub-elements in the auxiliary data. Otherwise, it must be a single parameter.
‡ The state pseudo-parameter must be either ... or the number of parameters that corresponds to the number of arguments in the initial state, __VA_ARGS__.

usage.param: Auxiliary data to be passed through the algorithm to the predicate, operation, and target. This argument may be either a parenthetic expression of any arity or a non-parenthetic expression.

The predicate that determines whether the algorithm should continue. This predicate must be a macro name that refers to a macro with a signature compatible with the following pseudo-signature:
pred(s, data, state)

The operation used to iterate the state. This operation must be a macro name that refers to a macro with a signature compatible with the following pseudo-signature:
op(s, data, state)

The target to be repeated. This target must be a macro name that refers to a macro with a signature compatible with the following pseudo-signature:
macro(s, data, state)
Auxiliary data to be passed through the algorithm to the predicate, operation, and target. This argument may be either a unary parenthetic expression or a non-parenthetic expression.

macro.para:
The macro itself expands to a in terms of (s). This , when invoked by , expands to the result of repeating the target while iterating the state until the predicate expands to 0. This is illustrated by the following pseudo-code (where D is data, M is macro, and O is op):
M(s, D, state) M(s, D, O(s, D, state)) ... M(s, D, O(s, D, ... O(s, D, state) ...))

The predicate, operation, and target are all invoked with the current , the auxiliary data (data), and the current state (state or __VA_ARGS__). The predicate must expands to 0, 1, or a in terms of (s) that expands to either 0 or 1. If the predicate ultimately expands to 0 the algorithm terminates. Otherwise, the target is invoked with the current state, the operation operation is applied to the current state to yield a new state, and the algorithm continues. Both the target and the operation may expand to in terms of (s). Expansion to a allows the predicate, operation, and target to recurse on themselves if necessary.

Invocations of the target (but not the predicate and operation) are trampolined such that each invocation is invoked with ((s)), where s is the original at the beginning of the algorithm (i.e. ()). This maximizes the utility of the .

The auxiliary data, data, is treated differently depending on whether it is parenthetic. If data is non-parenthetic, it is passed directly to the operation as a single argument. In C99, if data is a parenthetic expression of any arity, its sub-elements are passed to the predicate, operation, and target as individual arguments. In C (prior to C99) and C++, if data is a unary parenthetic expression, its sub-element is passed to the operation as a single argument (a parenthetic expression of any other arity is prohibited).
Ignoring the complexity of pred, op, and macro (each of which is invoked once for each variation of the state), each iteration of the state requires only a single .
This macro deduces the current and invokes . If the current is already known, direct use of is more efficient.
